Spring 2014 Nuclear Energy FRSEM-UA 512; class # 14600 Instructor: Antoine Cerfon  syllabus  Monday and Wednesday, 3:30-4:45 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) Nuclear power currently provides 13% of the world's electricity and is expected to play an important role in the diversified energy mix that countries are developing to meet the world's growing energy needs. Spring 2014 Architecture in the City FRSEM-UA 516; class # 14602 Instructor: Marvin Trachtenberg  syllabus  Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 10:00–11:00 a.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) This seminar introduces students to key themes in western architecture from prehistory to postmodernity. Spain in 1492: From the 'Moor's Last Sigh' to the Conquest of the New World FRSEM-UA 517; class # 16558 Instructor: Sarah Pearce  syllabus  Monday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday 3:30–4:30 p.m. The year 1492 in Spain is the very definition of a watershed. Urban Objects: How Things in the City Make Life Possible or (Almost) Impossible FRSEM-UA 518; class # 16559 Instructor: Harvey Molotch  syllabus Wednesday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 11:00 a.m.–noon We concentrate on very ordinary things: trash bins, stop signs, lamp posts, turnstiles, fences, and whatever else we encounter in the course of public city life. Encountering Martin Luther King, Jr. FRSEM-UA 519; class # 16575 Instructor: Philip Kunhardt  syllabus  Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Physics I (Tuesday and Thursday 12:30–1:45 p.m.)  Few historical figures are more revered or transcendent than Martin Luther King Jr. But as David Levering Lewis wrote thirty-five years ago, America’s canonization of him has draped him in such a cloak of mythology that “in a sense we have sought to remember him by forgetting him.” This course seeks to vividly remember the human being at the center of the most significant popular movement in U.S. history, one that took up the unfinished legacy of the Civil War and Reconstruction eighty years after the nation turned its back on social and racial justice. Students explore King’s thought, oratory, character, and public actions in a way that will make him unforgettable to them. We consider his tenaciously held philosophy of nonviolent social change, and his growth from a southern Baptist minister to a leading civil rights activist to a visionary leader of global human rights and peace. We ask if he was a radical or a moderate and why he felt history had “hunted him down,” as he once claimed to fellow activist Rosa Parks. In what ways can new information about his inner conflicts and personal flaws change our appreciation of his moral stature? And how do we understand him in the context of his times, amidst fellow activists, adversaries, elected leaders, and critics during one of the most volatile, freedom-advancing periods of American history? Using film and little-known radio interviews as part of the class research, as well a challenging immersion in some of the most significant King literature, the course, coming in the fiftieth anniversary year of the March on Washington, makes King and his times newly relevant to our own vastly changed but still violence-prone and violence-haunted world. He focuses on the lives of transformative figures and has co-authored five books, including Looking for Lincoln, The American President , and P.T. Barnum: America’s Greatest Showman . He was also writer and co-producer of more than a dozen documentary films for PBS, ABC, HBO, Discovery, and others, including the ten-part PBS series The American President , and the sixteen part Freedom: A History of US. Before coming to NYU he was a Bard Center Fellow at Bard College in Annandale, New York. Writing the Self and New York FRSEM-UA 520; class # 18468 Instructor: David J. Dent Tuesday, 3:30–6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Thursday 3:30–4:30 p.m. In this course students begin the semester by dusting off their college admissions essays. DENT is Associate Professor at New York University where he holds a joint appointment at the Arthur Carter Journalism Institute and in the Department of Social and Cultural Analysis. Spring 2014 Visuality and Literature FRSEM-UA 521; class # 14603 Instructor: Jennifer Cayer  syllabus  Tuesday and Thursday, 11:00 a.m.-12:15 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) In this course we examine twentieth-century and contemporary essays, novels, short stories and plays that are preoccupied with the visual, perform visually, or integrate images within narrative. Some of these works respond directly to pieces of visual art or analyze forms of seeing; others include images such as photographs or drawings. This is a writing-intensive course. While actively discussing the course materials, students consistently and frequently engage them through critical and creative, formal and informal writing. One of our goals is to deepen our own practices of seeing and using visual evidence as a method toward writing personal, exploratory, and persuasive essays. Topics may include: memoir, documentary works, photography, film adaptations, comics, graphic novels, artists books and surrealism. Spring 2014 Into the Urban Wild: Nature Writing and the City FRSEM-UA 522; class # 14604 Instructor: Tara K. Parmiter Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) Essayist Loren Eiseley asserts that “even in New York City there are patches of wilderness,” encouraging his readers to rethink the way they define and limit their use of this loaded word. In this course we examine both the idea and the manifestation of these wildernesses, questioning the assumptions and the rhetoric we use when talking about the existence, construction, representation, cultivation, or manipulation of nature in our urban environment. We immerse ourselves in classics of American nature writing and then venture into the city, using our texts as lenses for reading such spaces as Central Park, the High Line, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and the American Natural History Museum. Readings include selections by Henry David Thoreau, John Burroughs, Aldo Leopold, Rachel Carson, Loren Eiseley, Annie Dillard, Terry Tempest Williams, bell hooks, Wendell Berry, and William Cronon, among others. Students compose both critical analyses of the texts and their own nature writing based on their exploration of and research into their own “patch” of New York wilderness. TARA K. PARMITER is a Senior Language Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program and a Mentor in the Undergraduate Writing Tutors Program. Montgomery’s Anne of Green Gables novels to summer vacationing in Kate Chopin’s The Awakening to journey narratives in the Muppet movies. Spring 2014 Reading Toni Morrison FRSEM-UA 523; class # 14612 Instructor: Elizabeth McHenry Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.–noon Required cohort meeting: Thursday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Winner of the 1993 Nobel Prize for Literature, Toni Morrison was the eighth woman and first African American ever to receive that award. Our aim is to understand the formal aspects of her writing—how her novels “work” as literature—as well as the cultural and historical interventions it makes. We also take up questions about Morrison’s reputation among contemporary readers of her fiction, and the various outlets, including Oprah’s Book Club, where it has been championed. ELIZABETH MCHENRY, Associate Professor of English, is the author of Forgotten Readers: Recovering the Lost History of African American Literary Societies , which received the John Hope Franklin Book Award, the Society for the History of Authorship, Reading, and Publishing Book History Award, and the American Library Association Award for Non-Fiction. Spring 2014 Atlantic Migrations since 1600 FRSEM-UA 524; class # 14629 Instructor: Joe Lee  syllabus Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) The movement of people, voluntarily and involuntarily, from Europe and Africa across the Atlantic to North and South America since about 1600 is one of the epochal events in world history. It has had a major impact—and in many cases has left an indelible mark—on the histories of both the sending and receiving of societies and cultures, whether the multitudes involved moved as free men and women, as indentured servants, or as slaves. This course seeks to understand the causes and consequences, economic, social, political and cultural, of these massive movements of human beings. Casey. Nueva York, New York FRSEM-UA 525; class # 18469 Instructor: James D. Fernández Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Experimental Physics I (Monday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) Prerequisite: reading knowledge of Spanish and/or a score of 4 or 5 on any AP Spanish exam (or international equivalent). Spring 2014 Biography's Many Lives FRSEM-UA 526; class # 14605 Instructor: Victoria Olsen  syllabus  Thursday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) The genre of biography has traced lives of "famous men" since Plutarch and Boswell's Johnson, but its conventional forms and techniques have come into question over the last century. This course examines how biography provides a window into different periods, cultures, and disciplines and how it has had to stretch to incorporate new voices, methodologies, and techniques. From Virginia Woolf's Orlando to Rebecca Skloot's Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, biography has pushed the boundaries of literary form and scientific knowledge. We read a broad range of subjects and styles—exploring issues of research, writing, and reading—to become biographers of the genre itself. VICTORIA OLSEN, Ph.D. is a Senior Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program, where she teaches Writing the Essay to freshmen at Tisch and Writing and Speaking in the Disciplines to undergraduates in CAS. She is the author of the biography From Life: Julia Margaret Cameron and Victorian Photography.  Spring 2014 Cultures of Science and Belief FRSEM-UA 527; class # 14992 Instructor: Noelle J. Molé  syllabus   Monday and Wednesday, 2:00-3:15 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon We regularly take for granted that scientific knowledge is objective, a universal truth unchanged by history and culture. The laws of physics are just as true in Indonesia as they are in Mexico or the United States. Yet we also know that scientific knowledge is constantly in flux. What we “knew” to be true yesterday (e.g., the world is flat) is not true today, and new discoveries revolutionize what we knew (e.g., germ theory, epigenetics). This seminar positions science along a spectrum of worldviews—explanatory models that provide causal reasons and underlying logics for events and actions—a spectrum that includes magic, occultism, witchcraft, science, spirituality, and religion. A single hurricane might be explained, within particular historical and cultural contexts, as being sent by a witch’s curse, a moving cold front, or an angry god. How we position ourselves between these ways of knowing is not, of course, mutually exclusive and the threshold between the categories is actually more blurred than we might initially expect. Interrogating the similarities and differences between “knowledge” and “belief,” this course questions our deeply held assumptions regarding the neutrality of science and the so-called backwardness of folk belief. How do socio-cultural contexts and economic systems shape the production of scientific knowledge? Why do certain theories achieve recognition as rational and correct? We explore the social, economic, and political implications of these hierarchies of knowledge, and examine how they shape how we experience our own bodies, our own feelings, and even our own minds. NOELLE J. MOLÉ is a cultural anthropologist and author of Labor Disorders in Neoliberal Italy: Mobbing, Well-being and the Workplace . She is currently investigating the rise of scientific skepticism and supernatural beliefs in Italy as twin responses to a millennial crisis in knowledge production. She is a Senior Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program.  Spring 2014 The Art of Note Taking FRSEM-UA 528; class # 14606 Instructor: Louis Bury Wednesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 3:30–4:30 p.m. Taking notes is first and foremost a utilitarian act, a way of recording information for the purposes of future use and improved retention. But notes also possess, importantly, an aesthetic dimension: splayed across the page in poetic fragments, they present a veritable graph of a mind in motion. In this course we consider note taking as both an aesthetic and utilitarian act. Our course readings focus on exemplary notes, diaries, and journals by prominent 20th century writers and artists, as well as older species of textual response such as Talmudic commentary and marginalia on Medieval manuscripts. We may also consider contemporary forms of digital writing that verge on note taking, such as blog posts, tweets, and Internet commentary. We use these texts as both source material and inspiration for our own extensive note taking. The goal is not simply to help you to become a better note taker but to help you understand how note taking is itself a form of writing and of thinking and not merely preparation for the "real" writing that you submit to your professors. Course requirements include: weekly reading and note taking; a midterm presentation; one short essay; and a final research project, developed out of your weekly notes. LOUIS BURY is a Language Lecturer in the Expository Writing Program. His first book, Exercises in Criticism: The Theory and Practice of Literary Constraint (Dalkey Archive Press, forthcoming) applies rules and restrictions in order to write poetic, autobiographical literary criticism. He is currently taking notes for a book on literary note taking.  Spring 2014 Sensual Shifts: From Looking to Listening in Modernist Literature FRSEM-UA 529; class # 14607 Instructor: Angela Frattarola  syllabus Monday and Wednesday, 3:30-4:45 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). From Greek philosophy to the Enlightenment, vision was the privileged sense. Traditionally associated with knowledge and rationality, vision encourages a subject to keep a distanced, analytical perspective of an object. But does this always have to be the case? Can the other senses allow new ways of conceiving of and experiencing the relationship between the self and the world? This seminar begins by examining the dominance of vision in modernity and turns to audition as a way of thinking about alternative perceptions of the self and the world. We accomplish this by closely reading modernist novels that suggest a growing skepticism toward vision and heightened attention to sound and listening. In order to think about why modernists brought sound to the forefront of their art, we attempt to gain a sense of the modernist soundscape and the new auditory technologies of the time. Readings for the course consist of essays from sound studies as well as novels by Virginia Woolf, Dorothy Richardson, Jean Rhys, and James Joyce. ANGELA FRATTAROLA is a Senior Lecturer and Writing Tutor Mentor in NYU's Expository Writing Program. Her essays on modernist literature have appeared in such journals as Modern Drama, Genre, Mosaic, Studies in the Novel, Journal of Modern Literature, and Woolf Studies Annual . She has nearly completed a manuscript entitled Auditory Narrative in the Modernist Novel: Early Twentieth-Century Soundscapes and Audio-Technologies , a study that examines how modernist literature was shaped by developing auditory technologies and changes in auditory perception at the turn of the century.  Spring 2014 Rediscovering Bacchic Revelry FRSEM-UA 530; class # 15031 Instructor: Megan Shea  syllabus Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). When we think about the staging of ancient Greek theater, we often envision a static stage where a masked man recites a lengthy monologue in an outdoor theater. But such a vision hardly describes the dynamic celebration of music, sexuality, and poetry that infused the City Dionysia and the Lenaia—the Athenian festivals centered on tragedy and comedy in the sixth through the fourth Centuries B.C.E. In this seminar, we reimagine the performance of Greek theater by witnessing current productions of Greek plays, engaging with New York City’s various collections of Greek art objects, studying contemporary festivals and celebrations, poring through critical interpretations of Greek history, and returning to textual evidence (the plays!). Beyond reconstructing our own understandings of ancient performance, we use the discord between our original scenarios of Greek performance and our revisions to evaluate how we conceive of Western civilization’s past. Weekly response papers, a performance/design project, and a final research paper help awaken our sense of ancient performative acts. While teaching at Cornell, she received the Gertrude Spencer Student Portfolio Award, and she has received several Excellence in Teaching awards while at NYU. Dr. Shea has published articles in The Journal for Dramatic Theory and Criticism and TheatreForum . She recently premiered her translation of Euripides’ Cyclops at Dixon Place.  Spring 2014 Left Brain, Right Brain, Whole Brain: Acts of Knowledge, Discovery, and Creation FRSEM-UA 531; class # 14608 Instructor: David Ellis  syllabus  Tuesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Artists and scientists are often split into separate camps in the university and in our collective imagination; this split can even divide our individual minds. “Left brains”—the analytical, logical, objective among us—become engineers, biologists, and bankers while “right brains”—intuitive, thoughtful, subjective—are the painters, philosophers, and social workers of the world. In practice, in the science lab or in the artist’s studio, these distinctions may be more porous than we popularly believe. This seminar explores the interplay between reasoning, knowledge, belief, discovery, and creativity—acts of mind common to all fields in the academy. Whether presented to us in the “real world,” the arts, or philosophy, we will wrestle with conundrums which resist easy solution. We explore many branches—logic, physics, neurology, psychology, literature, film, visual and performance art—hunting for approaches to understanding which we then put into practice. We work towards the goal of “understanding our understanding,” as the artist Matthew Goulish phrases it, in order to exploit the twinned powers of rationality and creativity. Trips to MoMath (Museum of Mathematics), MoMA, and other outings are planned. In his “right-brained” work as a poet, fiction writer, and visual artist, DAVID ELLIS explores science topics with a humanities approach, such as the nature of time, memory, sensory perception, social dynamics, and spatial relationships. His work in NYU’s Writing in the Disciplines program has taken him into a range of “left-brained” classrooms, from astrophysics to psychology, and at the City University of New York he teamed up with a geologist and a classicist who specializes in Roman artifacts to teach a series a classes with shared research and creative practices, which was the basis of their work “Volcanoes, Vases, and Creation Stories.” He teaches in the Expository Writing Program at NYU. Natural and Artificial Intelligence FRSEM-UA 532; class # 18663 Instructor: Gary Marcus  syllabus Wednesday, 12:30–3:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Monday, 2:00–3:00 p.m. Prerequisite: Programming experience recommended. Who's smarter—Siri or Einstein? Is a "singularity" imminent? Through readings in psychology, philosophy, neuroscience, and computer science, we compare brains and computers, their relative strengths and weaknesses, and the prospects for human-level artificial intelligence. Topics include language, vision, game-playing, robotics, common-sense reasoning, and computational creativity. GARY MARCUS, Professor of Psychology and Director of the NYU Center for Child Language, is a cognitive scientist interested in the origins and nature of human mental life. His books include The Birth of the Mind: How a Tiny Number of Genes Creates the Complexity of Human Thought; The Norton Psychology Reader; and Kluge: The Haphazard Evolution of the Human Mind .  New Worlds, Old Worlds: Travelers and Pilgrims in Renaissance Europe and the Americas FRSEM-UA 533; class # 19001 Instructor: Jane Tylus Monday, 11:00 a.m.–1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 11:00 a.m.–noon Note: conflicts with Introductory Experimental Physics I (Monday 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.) Renaissance men—and women—found themselves at the intersection of colliding ideas about the worlds they lived in. They both looked back to antiquity and the Bible, and ahead to new and unpredictable changes regarding religion, geography, and science. The literature of travel in the period bears witness to the instability and excitement of the centuries that bear the hallmarks of the “early modern.” Travelers included pilgrims and knights going off on crusade and missionaries going off to convert, as well as explorers, merchants, and inevitably, exiles. If pilgrimage was about the return to a “center”—Jerusalem most prominently, but also Rome— exploration meant voyaging to an unknown periphery, and exilic wandering meant heading toward a new and uncertain home. We explore the period from roughly 1300 to 1700 through travel literature ranging from pilgrimage accounts to Columbus’s letters to an epic about the first Crusade. We also look at such alternate accounts as the Aztec version of the conquista and Arabic responses to the Crusades. The course includes visiting at least one museum in New York and studying cartographic images at the New York Public Library. Students produce collaborative in-class presentations as well as a final paper exploring their own personal journey through the new and old worlds they encountered during their first semester of college. JANE TYLUS is Professor of Italian Studies and Comparative Literature at NYU, as well as faculty director of the Humanities Initiative. Prior to coming to NYU in 2003 she taught at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. While her research focus of late has been on Italian women writers—she is the award-winning author of Reclaiming Catherine of Siena: Literature, Literacy, and the Signs of Others and translator of the poetry of Gaspara Stampa and Lucrezia Tornabuoni—she is really a comparatist at heart, and her favorite courses are on the "great books" of world literature. Her current projects are books on the beautiful Tuscan hill-town of Siena and on medieval and early modern pilgrimage. On Being Human FRSEM-UA 534; class # 19002 Instructors: G. Gabrielle Starr & Jane Tylus Thursday, 9:30 a.m.–noon Required cohort meeting: Friday, 12:30–1:30 p.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) and with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) The sciences are united by their method of inquiry into the natural world and the social sciences in their study of human behavior, but the humanities seem different —rich, heterogeneous, or perhaps even fragmented. Different or not, the humanities offer unique and powerful models that help us think about and understand the world we inhabit. These ideas include simile (with a focus on pain, trauma, and the medical humanities), evidence (digital humanities, archives, and jurisprudence), dialogue (music, drama), empathy (history and philosophy), and ekphrasis (art history and literature). The course features site visits to the places where humanist engagement matters (hospitals, archives, museums, and even law courts) and encourages students to reflect upon their possible career paths as well as the connections among different disciplines, eras, and methodologies. Finally, the course considers why New York City and NYU are crucial for the humanities in the twenty-first century, in light of the City’s diverse nature and NYU’s identity as a global university. G. Spring 2014 Cataclysm and Voice in the Twentieth-Century Novel FRSEM-UA 535; class # 15225 Instructor: Leeore Schnairsohn Tuesday, 3:30-6:00 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Friday, 11:00 a.m.-noon Note: conflicts with General Chemistry I recitations (Friday, 8:00 a.m.–1:45 p.m.) and with Advanced Chemistry I recitation (Friday, 11:00 a.m.–12:15 p.m.). The course examines how novelists of the twentieth century responded to the cataclysms, both conceptual and historical, of that slippery and multifarious period of time. At the century's opening, people were trying to get a grip on things like airplanes and telephones and relativity theory and the Russian Revolution. Concurrently, artists were changing the way they made art, and kept changing it as the century continued to provoke them. We read some astounding novelists and consider their voices in conversation with the cataclysms of their times. We also write in response to the ways our world is changing at the turn of this new century, and attempt experiments with fiction and essay to construct true slivers of experience that speak from our own historical position. The class period is divided between discussion of the week's reading and a creative writing workshop. In addition to a final critical essay, students are expected to contribute one piece of creative prose (likely some form of fiction) to the workshop, and complete weekly writing assignments (some creative, some in response to the reading, some both). His translations of the Russian poet Osip Mandelstam have appeared in Portals and Inventory ; he has also published review articles in the Slavic and East European Journal and Canadian-American Slavic Studies . He is at work on a vampire novel and a non-vampire novel.  Spring 2014 Race and Culture in Brazil FRSEM-UA 536; class # 15924 Instructor: Dylon Robbins Monday, 2:00-4:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Wednesday, 10:00–11:00 a.m. Note: conflicts with Principles of Biology I (Monday and Wednesday 9:30–10:45 a.m.) Brazil is often invoked in conversations about race and culture. Whether as an example of presumably more egalitarian race relations, or as a regional culture embodying an exceptional fusion of African, Indigenous, and European elements, Brazil is a model for understanding heterogeneity and difference. And yet it is also a nation frequently cited for its incidence of violence and extreme economic inequality. We explore some of the unique contradictions shaping Brazilian reality as related to notions of race and culture by tracing the history of race relations in the ongoing transformation of Brazilian culture, examining such key examples and events as slavery and the plantation economy, popular music, Carnival, populism, racial democracy, affirmative action, and urban and rural violence. How do race and culture coincide and diverge in Brazil? And what may we gather about these convergences and divergences from textual, musical, and cinematic examples? DYLON ROBBINS is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. Spring 2014 Lincoln in Time: Private and Public Transformations   FRSEM-UA 537; class # 16575 Instructor: Philip Kunhardt    syllabus Thursday, 11:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Required cohort meeting: Tuesday 2:00-3:00 p.m.   This seminar engages students in an exploration of Abraham Lincoln's  transformative leadership, a touchstone for all subsequent American  presidencies. We closely explore the personal Lincoln, always in the  context of his times and their challenges, and see how a series of  wrenching personal crises sorely tested but also helped forge Lincoln's  character. Through the study of key texts, through intensive group  discussion, and through written and spoken communication, the seminar  presents students with a series of questions: Is there a moral realm with  which human actors engage for good or ill? How do private decisions and  inner resolves impact unfolding events? And how do figures like Lincoln  manage to grow past limitations of viewpoint and errors of judgment to  embrace universal human values and commitments?  We examine Lincoln's role in the Civil War, his use of political rhetoric,  and his impact upon American civil liberties. How did the issues of  slavery and race intersect with his development as a public figure? How  was he influenced by other figures around him-southerners, abolitionists,  former slaves, politicians? And how did he learn to use words so  effectively to help produce social transformation? Concurrent with a close  study of Lincoln's written and spoken words, and of the political, social,  and interpersonal context of his times, students also wrestle with the  vital question of how they can construct their own lives. Spring 2014 Pirates, Privateers and Other Maritime Renegades of the Caribbean FRSEM-UA 538; class # 16278 Instructor: Edgardo Morales  syllabus Tuesday, 9:30 a.m.-12:00 p.m. Pirates, privateers and runaways of the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth century Caribbean fought, stole, lied and killed in order to make a living and either to collaborate with or oppose bosses and empires. Today, the Jolly Roger --the pirate flag-- is clearly displayed in toys and makes for compelling cinematic moments. In real life, however, flying that flag was a criminal act punishable with the death penalty. How must we think of Francis Drake, the most feared privateer of the 1500s, in the age of Jack Sparrow, the most renown of the fantasy pirates of our days? This class will approach the history of maritime renegades as an opportunity to develop historical research and writing skills, and to help us think critically about topics that might otherwise escape scholarly inquiry. While outsiders often described pirates and privateers as renegades, godless,   murderers and villains, privateer men like Francis Drake,   pirate women like Anne Bonny, or runaway slaves like Tom King lived at   the very center of important political questions of their age. Students will read academic books such as Villains of All Nations , by the historian Marcus Rediker, as well as original documents dating back to the age of piracy.
